titleproper.value: Guide to the Herman and Conway Associates Records <num>TAM.094</num>

author.value: Collection processed by Camille M. Purcell (1991) and Porsche Martin (2002).

publisher.value: Tamiment Library and Robert F. Wagner Labor Archives

addressline: Tamiment Library and Robert F. Wagner Labor Archive

creation.value: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace <date>2018-05-07T16:03:27</date>

corpname.value: Tamiment Library and Robert F. Wagner Labor Archives

abstract.value: Herman and Conway Associates was a labor relations consulting firm founded in the 1940's as a successor to Robert Maisel Associates. In its work on behalf of employees and employer associations, the firm dealt with the major labor and management relations issues that pervaded the post-World War II era. The collection includes some of the the firm's correspondence, memorandums and clippings. <emph render="bold">NOTE: This collection is housed offsite and advance notice is required for use.</emph>

p.value: Published citations should take the following form: <lb/><lb/>Identification of item, date; Collection name; Collection number; box number; folder number; <lb/>Tamiment Library/Robert F. Wagner Labor Archives <lb/>Elmer Holmes Bobst Library <lb/>70 Washington Square South <lb/>New York, NY 10012, New York University Libraries.
The provenance of this collection is unknown. The accession number associated with this collection is 1967.002.

Herman and Conway Associates, a firm of labor relations consultants, was the successor to Robert Maisel Associates. Although the exact year of succession could not be ascertained, the change was made sometime during the late 1940's. In its work on behalf of employees and employer associations, the firm dealt with important issues in labor- and management relations during the post-World War II era. Material on issues such as Communist involvement in labor organizations, government versus private ownership, health-care providers, public utilities and related topics are to be found within this collection. Richard Conway, while figuring in some of the correspondence and memos, does not appear to have played a central role. As far as one can judge from the records extant, Harry C. Herman had primary responsibility for the administration of the firm. He served in the infantry during World War II and reached the rank of lieutenant colonel. He was decorated with the Purple Heart twice and received the Silver Star and the Croix des Services Militaires of France. Mr. Herman was also instrumental in founding the Naval War College in Washington. He died on February 23, 1984 in Boca Raton, Florida.
<emph render="bold">NOTE: This collection is housed offsite and advance notice is required for use.</emph>

subject.value: Hydroelectric power plants |x Finance |x Law and legislation.
Labor unions and communism -- United States.
